attributes.action: change legislation for managing School Admissions Appeals. Admission is often refused solely on grounds of over-subscription. Schools should be required to retain a small percentage of places until after appeals have been heard. An appeal system where no child's case is ever upheld is simply non-sensical, pointless and patronising to families entering into the process.
attributes.action_prefix: We the undersigned petition the Prime Minister to
attributes.background: LEAs in the U.K. offer a government legislated appeal process for families of children who have underperformed in selection tests or been refused admission for other reasons. A number of schools are successful in defending all appeals from children regardless of their disability, social circumstance or reason for appeal - usually on grounds of over-subscription. If no child's appeal will ever be upheld at these schools, why does the government permit them to offer an appeals process at all? If schools were required to retain a small percentage of places until after appeals have been heard - this rather questionable practice of never upholding any child's appeal could be eradicated. Have we forgotten that as a society we are supposed to be acting in the best interests of children - not schools and their governors?
